newsitem.title: USA: CBOT soybeans mostly lower on crop tour data.
newsitem.headline: CBOT soybeans mostly lower on crop tour data.

text.p: CBOT soybean futures were mostly lower at midsession on bearish input from data released overnight from a crop tour of Illinois, a key U.S. soy producing state, traders said.
"Results from the crop tour and the weather are good," a trader said referring to the rationale behind the slide in soybean futures.

Crop scouts on the Professional Farmers of America tour of Illlinois overnight indicated the crop was making satisfactory progress. The average pod count from 189 fields was 1,075.7 in a three-foot by three-foot square.
That tally was down slightly from the tour's five-year average of 1,164.5 pods and down from last year's count of 1,171.6.
Overall good crop weather in the U.S. Midwest also pressured the market.
"The crop is improving, the weather has been beneficial to the crop," said Steve Bruce of E.D. and F. Man International.
Nearby September soybeans were higher on overall firm cash basis markets this week and tight supplies of soybeans.
At 1128 CDT, soybeans were 3-3/4 cents per bushel lower to 2-3/4 higher, with September up 2-3/4 at $8.03.
